metadata.title: Combined effect of influence of nano additives, combustion chamber geometry and injection timing in a DI diesel engine fuelled with ternary (diesel-biodiesel-ethanol) blends

Combined effect of influence of nano additives, combustion chamber geometry and injection timing in a DI diesel engine fuelled with ternary (diesel-biodiesel-ethanol) blends
Harish Venu a, *, V. Dhana Raju b, Lingesan Subramani c
a Department of Mechanical Engineering, Saveetha Institute of Medical and Technical Sciences (SIMATS), Chennai, 600077, India b Department of Mechanical Engineering, Lakireddy Bali Reddy College of Engineering, Mylavaram, A.P, 521230, India c Department of Automobile Engineering, Madras Institute of Technology, Chennai, 600044, India
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 16 February 2018 Received in revised form 23 January 2019 Accepted 22 February 2019 Available online 23 February 2019
Keywords: Ternary fuel Nano additive Combustion chamber DIESEL-RK Injection timing Exhaust emission
* Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: harishvenuresearch@gmail.com
ac.in (V.D. Raju), s.lingesan@gmail.com (L. Subramani
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.energy.2019.02.163 0360-5442/© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
The present experimental work focuses on the combined effect of nano additives, combustion chamber geometry and injection timing in a single cylinder diesel engine fuelled with ternary fuel (diesel-biodiesel-ethanol) blends. Ternary fuel (TF) is doped with alumina nano additives and the resulting fuel is termed as high performance fuel (HPF). HPF is subjected to different combustion chamber geometries and TRCC (torroidal re-entrant combustion chamber) geometry is found to be effective among other geometries. HPF operated at TRCC chamber is subjected to four different injection timings namely, 21obTDC (HPF-TRCC21), 22obTDC (HPF-TRCC22), 23obTDC (HPF-TRCC23) and 24obTDC (HPF-TRCC24) respectively. BTE is lowered for HPF-TRCC21 and HPF-TRCC24 by 4.53% and 1.22% while highest BTE of about 33.8% is achieved for 22obTDC in comparison with other blends such as DIESEL-HCC23 (32.75%), HPF-TRCC21 (31.41%) and HPF-TRCC24 (32.53%). Lowest BSEC profile was achieved for HPF-TRCC22. HPFTRCC22 resulted in lowered HC and CO emissions of about 9.18% and 16.83% in comparison with HPFTRCC23. HPF-TRCC21 resulted in lowered NOx emissions by 22.53% along with higher HC and CO emissions by 6.13% and 20.51% in comparison with HPF-TRCC23. Cylinder pressure and HRR of HPFTRCC22 stays at an acceptable range of 75.42 bar and 85.34 J/deg CA in comparison with other test blends. The DIESEL-RK theoretical simulation results are compared with the experimental study conducted at the same operating conditions and its revealed that TRCC combustion chamber geometry is better for enhanced performance and combustion characteristics.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Rapid increase in number of vehicle industries has escalated the exhaust emissions along with health hazards and global environment degradation. The air quality degrades tremendously with increasing vehicular emissions such as hydrocarbon (HC), carbon monoxide (CO), particulate matter (PM), nitrogen oxides (NOx) and smoke emissions for which the transportation sector is hugely responsible [1,2]. There is an inherent need for searching a suitable alternative fuel for transportation sector due to twin problems of stringent emission norms and depleting fossil fuel reserves. Biodiesel and ethanol received severe attention in recent years as it can
(H. Venu), dhanaraju.v@lbrce. ).
be blended with mineral diesel for achieving both energy and environmental benefits [3]. Biodiesel cannot be utilized up to 100% as alternative fuel, owing to its highly viscous nature and essential minor engine alterations [4]. The usage of alcohols (ethanol, methanol, n-butanol etc.) and its blends with diesel emerged as a typical binary fuel pattern at the beginning of 21st century [5]. However, binary blends posed a serious issue of phase stratification or mixture stratification which was minimized by appending mixture stabilisers that were pretty costlier [6]. Among various alcohol alternatives, ethanol is preferred widely due to its higher oxygen content (34% by weight) which helps in improving the combustion rate. Ethanol has higher octane number [7] and hence it is utilized directly in spark ignition (SI) engines. Compression ignition (CI) engines are preferred in transportation sector widely owing to its improved thermal efficiency.
It is interesting to note that, addition of biodiesel in limited
content (20%) in diesel þ ethanol blend resulted in mitigation of mixture stratification and lowered the dependency of high cost mixture stabilizers. This paved way for a ternary fuel pattern comprising dieselþ biodieselþ ethanol blends [8e10]. Considering the above blending proportions, a ternary fuel (TF) is prepared by blending 20% biodiesel, 10% ethanol and 70% diesel fuel which are found to be more stabilized blends as well as its properties lying closer to diesel fuel. However, the profile of resulting ternary fuel lay below the diesel fuel in terms of performance and emission characteristics, which is identified as the problem statement of this research. To overcome the above addressed limitation, the researcher decided to adopt three techniques in a phased manner towards improving the combustion and emission characteristics of identified TF, namely (i) Addition of nano additives, (ii) Modification of combustion chamber geometry and (iii) Injection timing variation.
Addition of nano additives in base fuel is found to affect the fuel properties significantly thereby resulting in effective oxidation of fuel precursors during combustion and thereby resulting in lowered exhaust emission [11]. Gumus et al. [12] examined the effect of aluminium oxide (Al2O3) and copper oxide (CuO) nano particles with diesel. Al2O3 and CuO addition in diesel leads to lowered BSFC of about 0.5% and 1.2% at moderate engine speeds and found that nanoparticle addition can enhance the dispersion rate, improve the engine performance and lower the exhaust emissions. Sivakumar et al. [13] investigated the effect of alumina nano additives in pongamia biodiesel and found that the BSFC is lowered and the BTE is improved owing to pooled effect of physical ignition delay, higher evaporation rate, prolonged flame sustenance and higher flame temperatures of alumina nano particles leading to complete combustion. Shaafi & Velraj [14] experimentally investigated the effect of alumina nano particles in binary and ternary blends and found cylinder pressure and HRR of alumina blended ternary fuel are higher owing to higher surface area to volume ratio of alumina. Moreover they found that the atomization rate and heat transfer rate are improved with nanoparticle addition. Raju et al. [15] experimentally investigated the effect of nano particles doped in tamarind biodiesel blend fuelled in a single cylinder diesel engine.
Combustion chamber geometry is also an important parameter to be considered when the fuel is altered since the standard hemispherical chamber is suitable only for diesel fuel. Bapu et al. [16] performed an experimental investigation on the influence of a modified piston bowl geometry (MHCC) in comparison with conventional piston bowl (HCC) in a single cylinder diesel engine fuelled with B20 (20% Calophyllum inophyllum methyl ester þ 80% diesel fuel). It was observed that there is a substantial increase in peak pressure with MHCC when CR is increased. Singh et al. [17] reported that with different combustion chamber geometries, desired levels of squish, tumble, swirl and turbulence can be initiated inside the combustion chamber and subsequent improvements in performance and lowered emissions can be achieved. Jyoti & Reddy [18] conducted on single cylinder four stroke diesel engine with three different combustion chamber geometries namely Hemispherical Combustion Chamber (HCC), Torroidal Combustion Chamber (TCC) and Torroidal Re-entrant Combustion Chamber (TRCC). In comparison with HCC, the BTE of TCC and TRCC were higher by about 2.94% and 3.28% while the BSEC dropped by about 1.3% and 3.1% owing to inducement of air swirl inside the combustion chamber leading to complete charge combustion with maximized energy liberation. Gafoor & Gupta [19] numerically investigated the influence of piston bowl geometry and initial swirl ratios on the diesel engines performance and emissions. For such investigation, three configurations with various d/D ratios (aspect ratio) and initial swirl ratio were considered for improved engine performance and minimized emissions.
Another strategy of improving the performance of engine with alternative fuels is modification in injection parameters such as injection timing and injection pressure since it makes direct impact in atomization, vaporization and influences the fuel droplet size variation. Shameer & Ramesh [20] conducted a brief assessment on researches pertaining to variation of Injection Timing (IT) and Injection Pressure (IP) on biodiesel fuelled diesel engines on combustion characteristics. They found that, with advancement in IT, there is an increase in in-cylinder pressure, peak pressure rise; HRR and ID period is prolonged as a result of rapid combustion rate in PCP. Deep et al. [21] conducted experimentation on a single cylinder diesel engine fuelled with B20 (20% castor oil biodiesel þ 80% diesel fuel) at various IT and IP. They modified the IT's in range of 21 , 23 and 25 while IP is varied by 200 bar, 250 bar and 300 bar respectively. It is observed that, for all the IP's the BTE is comparatively lower. Goel et al. [22] had done a comprehensive review on the impact of modifications in diesel engines with various IP, IT, combustion chamber geometry, etc for identifying optimum working condition. High IP's with advancement/retardation of IT can improve the engine performance significantly with lowered HC, CO and smoke emissions owing to betterment in combustion and improvement in air-fuel mixing rate. Ganapathy et al. [23] studied the effect of Injection Timing (IT), load, torque and engine speed in jatropha biodiesel fuelled diesel engine. Advancing the IT to 340CAD from a standard engine specified timing of 345CAD lowers the BSFC, HC, CO and smoke levels by 5.1%, 1.2%, 2.5% and 1.5%.
Based on the critical survey of literature presented, it is observed that there are so far no literature focused on the combined effect of nano additives, combustion chamber geometry and injection timing. With this strategic conception the current research focuses on preparation of ternary fuel, preparation of high performance fuel by blending with nano additives followed by the operation of high performance fuel in various combustion chamber geometries and injection timings. The problem definition and the objectives for the current study are depicted in Fig. 1.
1.1. DIESELeRK simulation engine software
The simulation software DIESEL-RK is designed for modeling the actual working processes of compression ignition engines with all necessary required operating parameters. It is engine simulation and optimization software. Any type of combustion chamber geometrical shapes can be modeled with inclusion of profile of swirl, sprayer location, multiple injection, and number of nozzles, diameter of nozzle, and direction of nozzle holes and also the interaction of the sprays with walls. This RK model has a capability to optimize the geometry of piston bowl shape as per the specified design. Further, it helps in presenting the visualization of fuel spray with the combustion chamber walls, air swirl movement and neighbouring sprays in the animation visual format. The performance, combustion and emission characteristics of diesel engine such as brake thermal efficiency, specific fuel consumption, air-fuel ratio, heat release rate, in-cylinder pressure, combustion duration, ignition delay, peak cylinder pressure, NOX formation and soot concentration can be analyzed critically when it is operated with various fuels at different operation conditions and also validate this simulation results with the experimental test data. In the multi zone combustion model, the spray is split into seven characteristic zones, as shown in Fig. 2. The seven characteristics zones are (1) Dense axial core of free spray (2) Dense forward front (3) Dilute outer sleeve of free spray (4) Axial conical core of near wall flow of air with high density of fuel drops (NWF) (5) Dense core of NWF (6) Dense forward front of NWF (7) Dilute outer surroundings of NWF. Further, hwfr represents the height of the forward front of the NWF
and bm represents the spray forward front. The border between the initial and main stages of spray evolution corresponds to the moment when the axial flow close to the spray tip starts to deform and break up, forming a condensed mushroom-shaped forward front. As the spray moves on, constant breakup of the spray forward part takes place and the front is renewed by new flying fuel portions. The delayed droplets move from the breaking front to the environment. The moving spray carries the surrounding gas with it. The core diameter in the cross section is about 0.3 of the spray outside diameter. Same operating conditions and fuel properties with engine specifications were used as input data to the software. In this phase of experimental work,
SDRCCHCC
Fig. 3. Design of piston bowl combustion
without altering the operating conditions of the engine, the piston bowl geometry is designed to have Hemispherical Combustion Chamber (HCC), Shallow depth Re-entrant Combustion Chamber (SDRCC), Toroidal Combustion Chamber (TCC), and Toroidal Reentrant Combustion Chamber (TRCC) which is depicted in Fig. 3. It means that the proposed methodology is capable of creating most of the bowl shapes used in practical diesel engines. Kuleshov [77] recommended the use of DIESEL-RK simulation software for optimization of operating parameters such as geometry of piston bowl, injection pressure, injection timing, compression ratio, number of nozzles and the various fuels to the diesel engine to generate improved performance, combustion and emission characteristics.
From the design and modeling of HCC, SDRCC, TCC and TRCC piston bowl geometries, considering the actual operating conditions of diesel engine at compression ratio 17.5, fuel injection timing of 220 CA and fuel injection pressure of 200 bar fuelled with high performance fuel (HPF) under same operating conditions and the simulation results are elaborated in the results and discussion.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of ternary fuel and assessment of its properties
sections.text:
With reference to above mentioned scenario, there is an inherent need of reducing the density, viscosity and improving the calorific value of JB100 to make it suitable for operation of diesel engine without causing any harm to engine as well as improving the engine performance. Government of India set itself high blending targets for biofuels as per the “National Biofuel Policy” approved on 24th December 2009 bywhich it is permitted to blend ethanol up to 10% and biodiesel up to 20% with diesel fuel by the end of 5th year plan (2017). It is interesting to note that, addition of biodiesel in limited content (20%) in dieselþ ethanol blend resulted in mitigation of mixture stratification and lowered the dependency of high cost mixture stabilisers. This paved way for a ternary fuel pattern comprising diesel þ biodiesel þ ethanol blends. Considering the above blending proportions, a ternary fuel (TF) is prepared by blending 20% biodiesel, 10% ethanol and 70% diesel fuel
which is found to be a more stabilized blends as well as its properties lying closer to diesel fuel. Hence, the ternary fuel blend was proposed to be developed with 20% biodiesel, 10% ethanol and 70% diesel fuel. Hence, the mixture is prepared for 1 L and is subjected to magnetic stirring for 2 h. The resulting mixture is named as TF and important fuel properties such as density, kinematic viscosity, calorific value, cetane number and flash point were determined for TF according to ASTM standards as shown in table. It is observed that, the density, viscosity and cetane number of TF were lowered by 2.52%, 26.73% and 8.16% in comparison with JB100 and higher than diesel fuel by 1.43%, 11.97% and 0.83% respectively. However, the properties are still not a match with mineral diesel. Hence, the researcher intended to adopt a novel technique of blending alumina nano additives with TF of about 20 ppm and further analyzing the property as well as performing experimentationwith nano additives doped ternary fuel blends. The properties of the blending stocks were mentioned in Table 3.
